did.abstract: Contains the papers of Tufts professor and performance artist Danielle Abrams, including audio and video recordings, photographs, idea notebooks, and other records related to her artwork and career.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains subject files, notebooks, audiovisual media, photographs, slides, correspondence, catalogs, clippings, digital media including 1 Mac computer, realia, puppets, and other materials documenting Danielle Abram's artistic career.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are organized in received order.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Danielle Abrams (1968-2022) was a performance artist and a professor of the practice at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts at Tufts from 2014-2022.

Danielle Abrams was born in Queens, NY, on March 30, 1968, to Stephanie Belkin Abrams, a teacher and guidance counselor, and Eddie Abrams, a post office driver and furniture mover. After graduating from John Bowne High School in Flushing, she received a B.F.A. in painting and art education from Queens College (1992) and an M.F.A. in performance, video, and installation from the University of California at Irvine (1998). She held artists' residencies at the Yale School of Painting (1990) and the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture (1992).

In addition to teaching high school in New York City and San Francisco, Abrams taught at the City University of New York, St. Francis College in Brooklyn, the University of Michigan, and Goddard College. She first came to the School of the Museum of Fine Arts (SMFA) at Tufts as a visiting artist in 2014, and later became a professor of the practice in performance. Her family's African-American and Jewish heritage, and her identity as a mixed race queer woman, informed much of her work, as did historical research.

She was a Faculty Fellow at the Tisch College of Civic Life and a Visiting Scholar at the Midlo Center for New Orleans Studies at the University of New Orleans. In 2018, she was presented with the Distinguished Artist Award from the St. Botolph Club Foundation. Abrams died in Boston, MA, on April 21, 2022.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Adrienne Pruitt, Collections Management Archivist, in summer 2022. Materials were placed in archival boxes and folders, and a box-level inventory was created. The finding aid was created at the time of processing.
